user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_virt2phys:
```c
static int metal_virt2phys(void *addr, unsigned long *phys)
{
	off_t offset;
	uint64_t entry;
	int error;

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0)
		return -EINVAL;

	offset = ((uintptr_t)addr >> _metal.page_shift) * sizeof(entry);
	error = pread(_metal.pagemap_fd, &entry, sizeof(entry), offset);
	if (error < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed pagemap pread (offset %llx) - %s\n",
			  (unsigned long long)offset, strerror(errno));
		return -errno;
	}

	/* Check page present and not swapped. */
	if ((entry >> 62) != 2) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "pagemap page not present, %llx -> %llx\n",
			  (unsigned long long)offset, (unsigned long long)entry);
		return -ENOENT;
	}

	*phys = (entry & ((1ULL << 54) - 1)) << _metal.page_shift;
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_virt2phys:
extern struct metal_state _metal
...
void metal_io_init(struct metal_io_region *io, void *virt,
	      const metal_phys_addr_t *physmap, size_t size,
	      unsigned int page_shift, unsigned int mem_flags,
	      const struct metal_io_ops *ops)
{
	const struct metal_io_ops nops = {
		NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL
	};

	io->virt = virt;
	io->physmap = physmap;
	io->size = size;
	io->page_shift = page_shift;
	if (page_shift >= sizeof(io->page_mask) * CHAR_BIT)
		/* avoid overflow */
		io->page_mask = -1UL;
	else
		io->page_mask = (1UL << page_shift) - 1UL;
	io->mem_flags = mem_flags;
	io->ops = ops ? *ops : nops;
	metal_sys_io_mem_map(io);
}
...
static int metal_shmem_try_map(struct metal_page_size *ps, int fd, size_t size,
			       struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	size_t pages, page, phys_size;
	struct metal_io_region *io;
	metal_phys_addr_t *phys;
	uint8_t *virt;
	void *mem;
	int error;

	size = metal_align_up(size, ps->page_size);
	pages = size / ps->page_size;

	error = metal_map(fd, 0, size, 1, ps->mmap_flags, &mem);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
			  "failed to mmap shmem %ld,0x%x - %s\n",
			  size, ps->mmap_flags, strerror(-error));
		return error;
	}

	error = mlock(mem, size);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "failed to mlock shmem - %s\n",
			  strerror(errno));
	}

	phys_size = sizeof(*phys) * pages;
	phys = malloc(phys_size);
	if (!phys) {
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	io = malloc(sizeof(*io));
	if (!io) {
		free(phys);
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0) {
		phys[0] = 0;
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
		"shmem - failed to get va2pa mapping. use offset as pa.\n");
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, -1, 0, &metal_shmem_io_ops);
	} else {
		for (virt = mem, page = 0; page < pages; page++) {
			size_t offset = page * ps->page_size;

			error = metal_virt2phys(virt + offset, &phys[page]);
			if (error < 0)
				phys[page] = METAL_BAD_OFFSET;
		}
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, ps->page_shift, 0,
			&metal_shmem_io_ops);
	}
	*result = io;

	return 0;
}
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that are provably unreachable (i.e., code that can never be executed) in the provided snippets. Reasons:

- metal_virt2phys: Every return is guarded by a runtime condition (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0, pread error < 0, and the page-present test). None of these conditions are compile-time constants, so the branches and the final assignment are potentially reachable at runtime. There is no code following an unconditional return that would be dead.

- The (entry >> 62) != 2 test examines the top two bits of a 64-bit value; this can yield 0,1,2,3 at runtime, so both the error-branch and the success path are reachable.

- The metal_log macro expands to a runtime if-call inside a statement-expression; it does not introduce unreachable code in the call sites.

- metal_shmem_try_map: the two branches of if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0) are both reachable depending on runtime state, and the loop inside the else branch is not statically unreachable.

Notes (not related to Rule 2.1 but relevant to code review): there are runtime robustness concerns (e.g., pread may return a short read of 0 which is not checked, shifting by values >= width is undefined if page_shift is out of range, passing -1 to an unsigned page_shift parameter) — these are not instances of unreachable code but should be checked separately.
